10.74.text: What a great day this is, isn't it?

12.82.text: It's not often you get to celebrate.

20.26.text:
you get to celebrate a 100th anniversary,
100 today.

24.97.text:
So when I was asked to give
the recognition speech,

28.81.text: it was really easy to say yes.

32.29.text: Well I'll give you the easy answer.

34.95.text:
If I hadn't gone to
Columbia Business School,

37.43.text:
I would never be where I am today,
I would never have had the career,

41.72.text:
the professional life,
the amazing journey that my life has been.

45.65.text:
And so I never forget and
I never stop being grateful.

50.32.text:
Gratitude seems to be
a major meme of the day.

54.34.text:
Oprah likes to keep
a gratitude journal and

56.58.text:
says it's the single most
important thing she's ever done.

61.30.text:
choosing an ambitious personal
challenge to take on each year.

64.80.text:
A recent goal was to write
a thank you note every day.

72.85.text:
I know couples who tell each other
every night before going to sleep

77.28.text:
what each was grateful for
at the end of every day.

83.19.text:
And I have a friend who says that when all
she can think of at the end of the day,

87.72.text:
all she can come up with is that there
was hot water in the shower that morning,

92.96.text: it wasn't that great a day.

95.62.text:
So that's what I'd like
to bring to you today,

97.57.text:
on the occasion of this
school's 100th anniversary.

101.62.text:
The ten reasons for which I am
grateful for Columbia Business School.

106.20.text: So let's start at the beginning.

108.42.text:
I am very grateful that
they accepted a girl.

120.34.text: >> I was one of four women in

126.62.text:
This was 1968,
women didn't really go to business school.

130.22.text:
I was a psychology and government major
at Smith College, a college for women.

135.47.text:
I took a lot of art history and
English literature.

138.64.text:
There's no reason Columbia should
have taken me but someone in

143.58.text:
Uris Hall woke up to the fact that
women could be successful in business.

148.63.text:
And they should at least be given a
chance, that it was the right thing to do,

153.47.text: and voila, I was in the Class of 1970.

156.73.text: So, thank you, Columbia Business School.

159.30.text: Which brings me to my second reason.

161.74.text:
I am grateful that they never
asked why I wanted to go,

173.44.text:
I confess it to you all today,
I went because I didn't want to type.

179.06.text:
More specifically, I needed a job and I
didn't want one that required me to type.

185.64.text:
I needed a job so that my fiance George,
we've been married for 46 years.

198.45.text:
school at Columbia and one of us needed
to work before we could get married.

203.65.text:
In 1968, if you were a woman and
you wanted a job in the commercial world.

209.07.text:
Your only choice at
the entry level was to type.

216.95.text: This was not the turn of the century.

220.61.text:
Someone told me, someone who took
pity on me, said they didn't think

224.67.text:
they could make someone,
even a woman, type if she had an MBA.

229.53.text:
It was hypothesis by the way,
not a sure thing.

234.40.text: Columbia never asked why I wanted to go.

237.13.text:
In those days, there were no essays and
there were no interviews.

240.40.text: They never asked and I never told.

242.47.text:
>> [LAUGH]
>> I will concede most women did not

246.25.text: go to such extreme lengths to not type.

249.39.text:
But here I am, so
thank you Columbia Business School.

253.51.text:
Three, I am grateful that they took
someone who scored at the 35th

258.47.text:
percentile on the math
portion of the GMAT.

264.03.text:
Okay, I did score at the 99th on verbal,
foreshadowing I guess.

269.02.text:
And I would have to observe that that
was not such a bad score for someone

273.12.text:
who had never seen a GMAT exam before,
entering the room the morning I took it.

278.07.text:
I took my seat that morning,
as someone who had not had a course in

282.45.text:
anything quantitative since
junior year of high school.

287.02.text: I guess they did want girls.

293.43.text:
to Columbia Business School for exposing
me to subjects I knew nothing about.

298.28.text:
Banking, finance, tax law,
operations research.

304.14.text:
Remember, I was the classic
liberal arts kid.

307.50.text:
To me,
college was all about studying Proust,

310.22.text:
Joyce, the origins of
the Russian Revolution.

313.98.text:
I didn't know about this practical stuff,
this real world stuff.

318.28.text:
So, thank you, Columbia Business School
for opening my eyes to a bigger world,

323.10.text:
to the real world, to the excitement
of capitalism and commerce.

326.95.text:
I've not only depended on these
subjects throughout my career, but

330.65.text: they've actually come in handy in my life.

333.83.text:
Even operations research, when George
was Chief Resident at the hospital,

339.06.text: I scheduled all the interns and residents.

341.71.text:
35 people across 12 rotations
over the space of 12 months,

346.46.text:
and I did it in 25 minutes,
because I knew OR.

352.58.text:
So thank you, Columbia,
for the knowledge, and

355.92.text: also for constantly piquing my curiosity.

359.25.text: I've actually never stopped being curious,

361.26.text:
that's why I'm on all those funny
boards that Dean Hubbard read out.

366.94.text: This was all nurtured at Columbia.

368.92.text:
Every day there was a talk on
a subject I knew little about.

372.34.text:
I went, I learned,
it made me even more curious.

377.39.text:
The content at the school itself and
the teaching set me up for

381.63.text: a life of seeking out the unknown.

384.38.text:
Business school itself pushed
me way out of my comfort zone.

388.98.text:
I seriously urge you to spend a portion
of your life being just a little

395.42.text: That's how you know you're learning.

397.44.text: People tend to run away from fear.

400.06.text: I have come to know it's a good thing and

403.12.text:
I also figure that I've spent about 50%
of my professional life in situations

408.47.text:
where I've been afraid because I had
never done before what I was about to do.

413.31.text:
Once you get over the I'm
really afraid part,

416.30.text:
you get to the,
this is really exhilarating.

420.74.text:
Thank you Columbia for teaching me
to not run away from the scary and

425.05.text:
the unknown, but
rather to run towards these moments.

428.74.text:
I've made it a way of life and
my life is richer for it.

433.71.text:
Five, I'm grateful that my education
gave me context, business context.

439.03.text:
While I was almost always being
asked questions about marketing and

442.33.text:
communications, I could present
the answers in a larger frame.

446.89.text:
I was never just the ad lady
bringing the storyboards.

450.66.text:
I could think of what I was presenting in
the context of a broader business strategy

455.31.text:
and I always made myself and my company
accountable to the client's business.

460.16.text:
The advertising, hopefully,
was brilliant but

462.93.text:
how would it make a difference
to the client's business?

466.75.text:
I always say about any marketing program,
eventually, somebody has to buy something.

474.43.text:
I made it a policy to
never work on any project

477.33.text:
without understanding the business
strategy and the idea behind it.

481.05.text:
I would recommend this to you as
a philosophy for your professional life.

485.79.text:
As for me, I thank you,
Columbia Business School.

490.34.text:
Six, I am grateful for the fact that
the CEOs of IBM, General Motors,

495.50.text:
Hewlett Packard, Kraft now Mondelez,
Pepsi, and Xerox are women.

501.56.text:
I could not have imagined
that this would be possible.

504.78.text: Yes that deserves applause, for sure.

512.34.text:
graduated from the business school in
1970, if you told me that this was going

516.24.text:
to be true at any moment in my lifetime,
I would have thought you were crazy.

521.24.text:
And while I can't give
direct credit to Columbia,

524.47.text:
I do believe that the fact that
almost 40% of the MBA class today is

528.95.text:
female will contribute to
changing the world of business.

532.98.text:
Until we arrive at the glorious moment
when men and women are represented in

537.97.text:
equal proportions as CEOs and gender
itself becomes completely irrelevant.

554.10.text:
continue to be impatient as we
move towards gender equality.

559.01.text:
And yes, I, too, thought we would’ve been
a little farther along than we are now,

563.36.text: but let’s celebrate where we are.

565.68.text:
Is there anything anyone now
believes a woman cannot do?

571.66.text:
Seven, I am grateful for
the friends I made while I was here.

577.19.text:
A few summers ago, my daughter and her
family visited old friends of mine from

581.23.text:
Columbia Business School, a man and
a woman in my class who married.

585.77.text:
They visited them at
their house in Normandy.

588.56.text:
When I saw the pictures of
my kids with their kids,

591.59.text:
my grandchildren with theirs,
it almost made me cry.

595.81.text:
I could still picture the three of
us sitting together side by side

600.28.text:
So look around you these are your
friends for life, how good is that.

615.76.text:
your grandchildren will be
playing with each other, and

619.34.text:
if you're lucky at all someone will
own a house on the beach in Normandy.

627.73.text:
the chance to stay
connected to the school and

630.53.text:
meet the amazing alums who
have passed through its doors.

634.05.text: You are now part of all this,

636.03.text:
part of this remarkable
Columbia Business School community.

639.59.text:
Going to a meeting of the Columbia
Business School Board of Overseers,

642.64.text: is a little like going to Davos.

644.67.text:
But without having to change in and
out of the boots eight times a day.

648.84.text:
It's simply makes me proud,
when I find out its some

652.39.text:
dazzling senior executive I've
met is actually a CBS graduate.

657.59.text: I usually want to hug him or her.

662.80.text: But we are a glorious ecosystem.

665.45.text:
I promise you, every week of your life,
you will run into a CBS graduate

671.27.text:
who will make you feel proud that you
are part of this remarkable community.

677.12.text:
Nine, I am grateful that Columbia Business
School enabled me to have a career in

681.40.text:
something that makes as big a difference
to the world, as business does.

685.13.text:
I know there's been lots of press
recently about how Americans no longer

690.13.text:
I came across a chilling statistic
a few weeks ago that only 16%,

694.82.text:
that's one sixth,
of Americans trust CEO's today.

699.27.text:
And if it makes you feel any better
members of Congress are even further down

704.87.text: As John McCain likes to joke,

706.66.text:
we in Congress are down to only blood
relatives and paid staff who respect us.

713.99.text:
we do have a challenge in this country
right now to turn around the perception

718.61.text: that business people are somehow evil.

721.73.text:
I believe it's our collective
responsibility to get people to see

725.05.text:
capitalism as a force for good,
a force for innovation because it is.

730.17.text:
When people question whether capitalism
has a future any more I think about

734.62.text:
micro- finance where people of no means
secure better lives through capital,

739.42.text:
capital that allows them
to grow businesses.

742.22.text:
I think about a business woman
from Africa at a session in Davos,

745.82.text:
who said if you really
want to help our country,

748.98.text:
instead of sending us charity,
please build factories.

753.55.text:
Put our people to work, help us grow our
economy, business as a force for good.

759.50.text: Business as an engine of innovation.

761.46.text:
The major inventions of our time
are all things funded by business and

766.24.text:
made available and accessible to
the greater public by business.

770.19.text:
The lightbulb, the automobile,
the personal computer.

773.82.text: And some of the companies responsible for

775.75.text:
these innovations just continue to create
things that make our lives better.

780.13.text:
IBM's Watson is diagnosing cancer faster
and more accurately then doctors,

785.62.text:
GE is developing desalination
technology aimed at making

789.81.text:
97.5 percent of the world's
water drinkable,

793.82.text:
do not ask me where they got
the number 97.5, but it's a lot.

799.56.text:
We live in a world that's
being transformed and

804.17.text:
The most optimistic, the most hopeful
thing I can say to you this afternoon

809.33.text:
is that you will indeed be
part of this transformation.

812.57.text: You will be leading it, in fact.

814.92.text:
And I can't think of
anything more exciting.

818.08.text:
And finally, at number ten on my list,
I am grateful that in the halls of Uris,

824.73.text:
I found a subject, an industry, a calling
in which I was passionately interested.

831.67.text:
Never underestimate
the importance of passion.

835.27.text:
If you ask me, what is the one consistent
attribute present in all great leaders,

843.17.text:
Passionate beliefs, passionate
communication, passionate action,

852.34.text: Who are the people you really admire?

856.60.text: Who is on your list of great leaders?

858.92.text:
I'm willing to bet that they are people
who are passionate about what they do.

863.49.text:
You know,
unfortunately words like exhilaration,

867.91.text:
joy, love, and passion are not
words usually applied to business.

872.91.text:
But not only can words like these
be part of the business world,

877.00.text:
I believe they are the key elements of
success and essential to true leadership.

881.60.text: Here's the whole secret of life!

883.03.text: I'm about to give it to you right now!

885.75.text:
Find something you love to do and
pursue it with passion.

890.83.text: I know it sounds too simple,

893.70.text:
maybe even simplistic, but
that doesn't make it any less true.

899.28.text:
I think finding real fulfilment and
joy in your job is the ultimate challenge.

904.00.text:
Because it's the key to
success on every level.

906.67.text:
People who succeed tend
to love what they do.

911.12.text:
People who succeed in finding balance in
their lives always love what they do.

919.81.text: I love the J.M. Barrie quote that goes,

923.95.text:
it's only work if you'd
rather be somewhere else.

929.43.text:
I am grateful to be here
with you today celebrating

932.23.text:
the 100th anniversary
of this great school.

934.51.text: It has made a huge difference to my life.

937.36.text: I'll bet anything that it will to yours.

939.96.text:
Make a note to yourself for
20 years from today to ask yourself

944.90.text:
how much difference your Columbia
Business School education has made.

952.70.text: Everyone will have a different answer, but

954.99.text:
I predict that no one will not be
affected in some significant way

960.62.text:
by what you've just experienced in
the halls of Columbia Business School.

969.68.text:
Congratulations to all in
the audience who have supported you,

973.99.text:
encouraged you,
put up with you, who love you.

978.75.text: This is a wonderful day for them, as well.

981.98.text:
May you thrive,
may you love what you choose to do.

986.08.text:
May your journey be interesting and
rewarding.

991.73.text:
May you have fun and never lose your
sense of humor or your perspective.
